content: How can I help you today?
I'm not sure. My wife insisted I come here, but I’m skeptical if this will really help. Things are just really overwhelming right now, and I don’t know where to start.

It sounds like you’re feeling a bit skeptical and unsure about this process, which makes sense given how overwhelming things feel right now. Starting can be hard when there’s so much on your plate. What’s been feeling overwhelming for you lately?

It’s mostly everything at home. My son’s behavior is a constant struggle, and it’s driving a wedge between me and my wife. We don’t know how to help him, and it feels like it’s tearing our family apart. I’m just exhausted and don’t know what to do next.

It sounds like you’re carrying a lot right now—worry for your son, tension in your relationship, and the weight of feeling exhausted without clear answers. That’s a tough place to be. You’re here talking about it, though, which shows strength. What’s been most difficult for you in dealing with this situation at home?

I think it’s the feeling of powerlessness. No matter what I try, I just can’t seem to help my son, and that’s tearing me apart. At the same time, my wife and I are arguing more because we’re both so stressed, and it feels like we’re slipping away from each other instead of working together. It’s like I can’t seem to fix anything, and it’s crushing me.

That feeling of powerlessness sounds really heavy—wanting so badly to help your son and mend things with your wife, but feeling like the solutions are out of reach. It’s understandable why that would feel crushing. You clearly care deeply about your family and want to make things better. What does working together with your wife and supporting your son look like to you, ideally?

I guess ideally, we’d be on the same page—working as a team rather than feeling like we’re in constant conflict. I’d want us to find a way to help our son, to understand what’s causing his behavior and figure out how to support him. And I’d want to feel like we’re a solid foundation for both our kids, instead of everything feeling so unstable. But honestly, I have no idea where to even start with all that.

It sounds like unity and understanding are really important to you—creating stability for your family and working as one with your wife to support your son. That shows how much you value your relationships and the kind of environment you want to build at home. Not knowing where to start can feel daunting, but you've already identified what matters most to you, which is a meaningful step. What feels like the biggest barrier right now to moving toward that vision?

It’s hard to say—I think it’s just everything piling up at once. My wife and I can’t seem to agree on how to address our son’s behavior, so we end up clashing more than cooperating. And when those arguments happen, it feels like we lose even more ground as a family. That tension spills over into everything else, and I just end up feeling stuck.

It sounds like the disagreements with your wife over how to tackle your son’s behavior are creating a cycle of tension and leaving you feeling stuck. That’s a tough place to be, especially when you’re wanting to work together and feel united during such a challenging time. What steps, even small ones, feel possible right now to improve communication with your wife or to find common ground?

It’s hard to say what could work. We’ve tried talking, but it usually ends in frustration. Maybe if we had some guidance or a way to approach things differently, it would help, but I just don’t know where to find that. It’s hard to trust anything will make a difference.

It sounds like you’ve already tried communicating, but the frustration keeps getting in the way. You're open to the idea of guidance or a new approach, even if it feels hard to trust that it will help right now. That willingness shows how much you care about making a change for your family. How do you feel about exploring outside support, like speaking with a counselor or family therapist, to navigate these challenges together?

I’m hesitant, honestly. The idea of talking to someone else about our problems feels uncomfortable, and I’m not sure it would really help us. But at the same time, I don’t want things to keep going like this, so maybe it’s something we could try.

It’s understandable to feel hesitant—sharing personal challenges with someone outside the family can feel uncomfortable at first. But it also sounds like part of you is open to the idea if it could help break the cycle and bring some calm back to your family. That openness is significant. What would make seeking outside support feel less intimidating for you?

Maybe if we found someone who really understood what we’re going through, someone who could guide us without judgment, it’d feel less intimidating. It’d help if my wife and I both felt like we could trust the person and actually see some steps forward. Honestly, I just don’t want to feel like it’s one more thing that doesn’t work.

It makes sense that trust and understanding would be key for you in seeking support. You want guidance, but in a way that feels nonjudgmental and genuinely helpful, especially since you're cautious about investing energy into something that doesn’t bring results. Just considering this option shows how committed you are to finding a way forward for your family. Is there anything else you’d like to talk through about this or what’s been weighing on you before thinking about next steps?
No, I think we’ve covered a lot of what’s been on my mind. Thank you for listening and helping me start to sort through this. For now, I need some time to process everything we’ve talked about.
